questions.question: Identify the type of nerve fibre in the diagram below.
questions.explanation: In the given figure, the fibre in yellow innervates the ends of the muscle spindle. Therefore, it is a gamma motor neuron. Many much smaller gamma motor neurons are located in the spinal cord anterior horns (shown as the yellow efferent fibre). These gamma motor neurons average 5 micrometers in diameter, which go to small, special skeletal muscle fibres called intrafusal fibres or the muscle spindle. These fibres constitute the ends of the muscle spindle, which help control basic muscle tone. Option (B): The alpha motor neurons (shown as the blue efferent fibre) are on an average 14 micrometers in diameter. These fibres branch many times after they enter the muscle and innervate the large skeletal muscle fibres at the motor endplate. Stimulation of a single alpha nerve fibre excites anywhere from three to several hundred skeletal muscle fibres, which are collectively called the motor unit. Option (C): A-beta fibres are fibres for touch and pressure. Option (D): A-delta fibres are fibres for pain and temperature. questions.question: Which of the following is false with respect to muscle spindles?

options.A: The intrafusal and extrafusal fibers are positioned parallel to each other
options.B: The primary endings of intrafusal fibers are most sensitive to a dynamic response
options.C: Type II nerve fibers do not innervate static nuclear bag fibers
options.D: Two types of gamma motor neurons supply the muscle spindle

questions.explanation: Type II nerve fibers do innervate the static nuclear bag fibers. They do not innervate dynamic nuclear bag fibers. A muscle spindle has: Intrafusal fibers - these are tiny skeletal muscles which have few or no actin and myosin filaments in the central portion. This portion acts as a sensory receptor. Extrafusal fibers. These fibers are positioned parallel to each other (Option A). There are two types of intrafusal fibers: Nuclear bag fibers - subdivided as dynamic and static nuclear bag fibers. Nuclear chain fibers. Sensory nerve supply: There are two types of sensory endings: Primary endings - (annulospiral ending) from Type Ia nerve fibers. This innervates both the nuclear bag and nuclear chain fibers. They are most sensitive to the velocity of the change in muscle length. This is called a dynamic response. (Option B) Secondary endings - from Type II nerve fibers. This innervates static nuclear bag and nuclear chain fibers. They do not innervate dynamic nuclear bag fibers. (Option C) Both primary and secondary endings show a static response. Motor nerve supply: The muscle spindles are supplied by gamma motor neurons. There are two types of gamma motor neurons - dynamic that supply dynamic nuclear bag fibers and static that supply static nuclear bag fibers and nuclear chain fibers. (Option D)

questions.question: The afferents for deep tendon reflexes innervate
questions.explanation: The afferents for deep tendon reflexes innervate both - nuclear bag and chain fibers. The afferents for the DTRs are the type Ia and type II nerve fibers. There are three types of intrafusal muscle fibers: dynamic nuclear bag, static nuclear bag, and nuclear chain fibers. A single Ia afferent fiber innervates all three types of fibers to form a primary sensory ending. A group II sensory fiber innervates nuclear chain and static bag fibers to form a secondary sensory ending. Deep tendon reflexes are an example of stretch reflex or myotatic reflex.

questions.question: Withdrawal reflexes are not

options.B: Prolonged if the stimulus is strong
options.C: An example of a flexor reflex
options.D: Accompanied by the same response on both sides of the body

questions.explanation: Withdrawal reflexes are not accompanied by the same response on both sides of the body. On the ipsilateral side of the pain stimulus, flexors are stimulated (they contract) and extensors are inhibited (they relax), and the arm is jerked away from the stove. On the contralateral side, flexors are inhibited and extensors are stimulated (crossed extension reflex) to maintain balance. It results in flexion on the ipsilateral side and extension on the contralateral side. Somatosensory and pain afferent fibers elicit withdrawal of the stimulated body part from the noxious stimulus. Pain (e.g., touching a hot stove) stimulates the flexor reflex afferents of groups II, III, and IV. The afferent fibers synapse polysynaptically (via interneurons) onto motoneurons in the spinal cord. As a result of persistent neural activity in the polysynaptic circuits, an afterdischarge occurs. The afterdischarge prevents the muscle from relaxing for some time. Spinal cord, nociceptor, painful stimulus. One collateral activates ascending pathways for sensation (pain) and postural adjustment (shift in center of gravity). Withdrawal reflex pulls foot away from painful stimulus. Crossed extensor reflex supports body as weight shifts away from painful stimulus.

questions.question: The maintenance of normal posture depends on

options.D: Joint movement in a physiological range

questions.explanation:
The maintenance of normal posture depends on the integrity of the reflex arc. The muscles that maintain upright posture—that is, support the body's weight against gravity—are controlled by the brain and by reflex mechanisms. Three levels of the nervous system control movement: 
   • The spinal cord, which integrates spinal reflexes and contains central pattern generators.
   • The brain stem and cerebellum, which control postural reflexes and hand and eye movements.
   • The cerebral cortex and basal ganglia, which are responsible for voluntary movements.

   Signals from the vestibular apparatus directly go to the cerebellum. 
   Output signals initiate movement without higher input. 
   Postural and spinal reflexes do not require integration in the cortex.

questions.question: Receptor for inverse stretch reflex
questions.explanation: Golgi tendon organ is the receptor for inverse stretch reflex (refer figure). The Golgi tendon organs, unlike the spindles, are in series with the muscle fibers; therefore, they are stimulated by both passive stretch and active contraction of the muscle. The degree of stimulation by contraction of muscles is much greater than that caused by the stretching of muscles. Muscle contraction → Ib fibers from the Golgi tendon organ excite an inhibitory interneuron that releases inhibitory mediator glycine → hyperpolarization (inhibition) of α motor neurons → muscle relaxation. questions.explanation: There are 3-20 muscle fibers per Golgi tendon organ. Golgi tendon organ consists of a netlike collection of knobby nerve endings among the fascicles of a tendon. There are 3-25 muscle fibers per Golgi tendon organ. The fibers from the Golgi tendon organs make up the Ib group of myelinated, rapidly conducting sensory nerve fibers. Golgi tendon organs help in regulating the velocity of the muscle contraction, muscle length, and muscle force. They are the receptor for inverse stretch reflex. questions.question: The inverse stretch reflex

options.A: Occurs when Ia spindle afferents are inhibited
options.B: Is a monosynaptic reflex initiated by activation of the Golgi tendon organ
options.C: Is a disynaptic reflex with a single interneuron inserted between the afferent and efferent limbs
options.D: Is a polysynaptic reflex with many interneurons inserted between the afferent and efferent limbs

questions.explanation: Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/Inverse stretch reflex) is disynaptic, is the opposite, or inverse, of the stretch reflex. When tension on the muscle - and therefore on the tendon - becomes extreme, the inhibitory effect from the Golgi tendon organ can be so great that it leads to instantaneous relaxation of the entire muscle. This effect is called the lengthening reaction; it is probably a protective mechanism to prevent tearing of the muscle or avulsion of the tendon from its attachments to the bone. Inverse stretch reflex: 1. Excessive muscle contraction, 2. Golgi tendon organ activated, Ia and Ib afferent fibers, dorsal column, inhibitory interneuron, a motor neuron, 4. Muscle relaxation. 3. A motor neuron is inhibited.

questions.question: All of the following are true about withdrawal reflex except

options.A: Diverging circuits to spread the reflex to the necessary muscles for withdrawal are present
options.B: Circuits to inhibit the antagonist muscles, called reciprocal inhibition circuits, are present
options.C: Circuits to cause afterdischarge that lasts many fractions of a second after the stimulus is over are present
options.D: The pathways for eliciting the flexor withdrawal reflex pass directly to the anterior motor neurons, making it a monosynaptic reflex

questions.explanation: The pathways for eliciting the flexor withdrawal reflex do not pass directly to the anterior motor neurons; instead, they first pass into the spinal cord interneuron pool of neurons and only secondarily to the motor neurons. The shortest possible circuit is a three- or four-neuron pathway. The following basic types of circuits are present: diverging circuits to spread the reflex to the necessary muscles for withdrawal; circuits to inhibit the antagonist muscles, called reciprocal inhibition circuits; and circuits to cause after-discharge are present. They prolong the reflex contraction of the muscles that last many fractions of a second after the stimulus is over. The flexor reflex is organized to withdraw a pained or otherwise irritated part of the body from a stimulus. Further, because of after-discharge, the reflex can hold the irritated part away from the stimulus for 0.1 to 3 seconds after the irritation is over. During this time, other reflexes and actions of the central nervous system can move the entire body away from the painful stimulus.

questions.question: Muscle tone is maintained by
questions.explanation: The resistance of a muscle to stretch is often referred to as its tone or tonus and muscle spindle helps to control basic muscle tone. The tonic (static) stretch reflex circuit includes both group Ia and group II afferent fibers from muscle spindles. Normally, there is ongoing activity in the Ia and II afferents that helps maintain a baseline firing of alpha motor neurons; therefore, the tonic stretch reflex contributes to muscle tone.

questions.question: Which of the following is true during initiation of voluntary movements?

options.A: Alpha motor neurons are activated followed by gamma motor neurons
options.B: Gamma motor neurons are activated followed by alpha motor neurons
options.C: Both alpha and gamma motor neurons are activated together
options.D: Only alpha motor neurons are activated

questions.explanation: The cell bodies of alpha and gamma motor neurons to a given muscle lie close together. Both types are activated by interneurons in their immediate vicinity and sometimes directly by neurons of the descending pathways. During many voluntary and involuntary movements, they are coactivated, i.e., they are excited at almost the same time. (Alpha-gamma coactivation) The purpose of alpha-gamma coactivation: • First, it keeps the length of the receptor portion of the muscle spindle from changing during the course of the whole muscle contraction. Hence, the muscle contraction is not opposed by the stretch reflex. • Second, if the muscle spindle did not contract and relax along with the large muscle fibers, the receptor portion of the spindle would sometimes be flail and sometimes be overstretched. Coactivation thus ensures that information about muscle length will be continuously available to provide for adjustment during ongoing actions and to plan and program future movements.

questions.question: Righting reflex is
questions.explanation: Righting reflexes operate to maintain the normal standing position and keep an animal's head upright. These reflexes are a series of responses integrated for the most part in the nuclei of the midbrain.

questions.question: In a patient with decerebrate rigidity, on applying pressure on the footpad, extension of that limb occurs. Which of the following statements is false regarding this phenomenon?

options.B: It is integrated at the Spinal Level
options.C: It helps to prevent falling on that side
options.D: It is a righting reflex integrated at midbrain level

questions.explanation: Pressure on the footpad of a decerebrate patient causes the limb to extend against the pressure applied to the foot. This reflex is called the positive supportive reaction and is a righting reflex integrated at the spinal level. Pressure on one side causes extension in that direction (e.g., on applying pressure on the right footpad, extension of the right lower limb occurs), an effect called the magnet reaction. It is seen in infants and following spinal transection. From an evolutionary perspective, this reflex helps to prevent falling on the side where the stimulus is given.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about the corticospinal tract?
questions.explanation: The corticospinal tract contains crossed fibers (the majority). Fibers of the corticospinal tract originate from the primary motor cortex (about 30%), the premotor and supplementary motor areas (30%), and the somatosensory areas posterior to the central sulcus (40%). Most fibers (80% of fibers) decussate (cross) in the medullary pyramids and descend in the lateral white matter of the spinal cord to form the lateral corticospinal tract. They control the movements of the contralateral limbs. The remaining 20% make up the ventral corticospinal tract. These fibers remain uncrossed until reaching the spinal cord, where axons terminate bilaterally on spinal interneurons antecedent to motor neurons. These fibers control the movements of the axial musculature. Primary motor cortex = 30%, premotor area and supplementary motor area = 30%, somatic sensory parietal areas = 40%. The precentral gyrus (area 4), premotor, and supplementary motor (area 6) pass through the posterior limb of the internal capsule. The corticospinal tract forms the pyramids of the medulla. The majority cross at the lower part of the medulla to the opposite side. Fibers that do not cross pass ipsilaterally down the cord. Pyramids, ventral corticospinal tract (20% of fibers), and corticospinal tract are related. The internal capsule is involved in the decussation of the pyramids. The lateral corticospinal tract (80% of fibers) and ventral corticospinal tracts are formed. Anterior horn cells, interneurons, spinal nerves, lateral corticospinal tracts, and ventral corticospinal tracts are related to distal and proximal muscles.

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding the origin of corticospinal tract?

options.A: Corticospinal tract fibers originate from Betz cells
options.B: 30% from premotor and supplementary motor areas

questions.explanation: 30% of corticospinal tract originates about from the primary motor cortex, not 90%. 30% are from the premotor and supplementary motor areas. 40% are from the somatosensory areas posterior to the central sulcus. Betz cells, some large myelinated fibers in the corticospinal tract, originate from giant pyramidal cells, also known as Betz cells. Found in the layer 5 of primary motor cortex. These large fibers represent only 3 percent of the total fibers of the corticospinal tract. (The other 97 percent, less than 4 micrometers in diameter, conduct background tonic signals to the motor areas of the cord.) questions.question: Which of the following is not an extrapyramidal tract?
questions.explanation: Corticospinal tract is a pyramidal tract. Pyramidal tracts (corticospinal and corticobulbar) pass through the medullary pyramids. All others are extrapyramidal tracts and originate primarily in the brain stem.

questions.question: Which pathway is not involved in maintenance of posture?
questions.explanation: Rubrospinal tract is not involved in posture maintenance. Medial motor system • Controls the axial muscles (muscles of the trunk) • Axial muscles are concerned with postural adjustments and gross movements. Lateral motor system • Controls the distal muscles • Distal muscles mediate fine, skilled movements. questions.question: Gamma motor neurons are mainly influenced by
questions.explanation: • The pontine and medullary reticulospinal tracts are involved in maintenance of posture and in modulating muscle tone, especially via an input to gamma motor neurons. • Pontine reticulospinal neurons are primarily excitatory, and medullary reticulospinal neurons are primarily inhibitory. • Stimulation of gamma-motor neurons does not lead directly to detectable contraction of the muscles because the intrafusal fibers are not strong enough or plentiful enough to cause shortening. • However, stimulation does cause the contractile ends of the intrafusal fibers to shorten and therefore stretches the nuclear bag portion of the spindles, deforming the endings, and initiating impulses in the Ia fibers. This in turn can lead to reflex contraction of the muscle. • Thus, muscles can be made to contract via stimulation of the alpha-motor neurons that innervate the extrafusal fibers or the gamma-motor neurons that initiate contraction indirectly via the stretch reflex.

questions.question: According to Herrington classification, the decerebrate rigidity is characterized by all except

options.A: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
options.B: Increase in the rate of discharge of the efferent neuron
options.C: Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
options.D: Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock

questions.explanation: In decerebrate rigidity, there is rigidity in extensor muscles of all the four extremities (not all muscles of the body). Decerebration: Complete transection of the brain stem between the superior and inferior colliculi permits the brain stem pathways to function independently of their input from higher brain structures. This is called a mid-collicular decerebration. This lesion interrupts all input from the cortex (corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts) and red nucleus (rubrospinal tract), primarily to distal muscles of the extremities. The excitatory and inhibitory reticulospinal pathways (primarily to postural extensor muscles) remain intact. The dominance of drive from ascending sensory pathways to the excitatory reticulospinal pathway leads to hyperactivity in extensor muscles in all four extremities, which are called decerebrate rigidity. The excitatory input from the reticulospinal pathway activates gamma-motor neurons, which indirectly activate alpha-motor neurons (via Ia spindle afferent activity). This is called the gamma loop. Option 4: Spinal shock is different from decerebrate rigidity as it is a transient state that can occur immediately after a spinal cord injury. It is characterized by a temporary loss or depression of spinal reflexes below the level of the injury.

questions.question: Which of the following is true for decorticate rigidity?

options.A: It is produced by the removal of the cerebral cortex and basal ganglia
options.B: Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occur
options.D: It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs

questions.explanation: • Removal of the cerebral cortex (decortication) produces decorticate rigidity. • Characterized by flexion of the upper extremities at the elbow and extensor hyperactivity in the lower extremities. • The flexion can be explained by active rubrospinal excitation of flexor muscles in the upper extremities; the hyperextension of lower extremities is due to the same changes that occur after midcollicular decerebration.

questions.question: Which of the following reflexes is absent in a decorticate animal?
questions.explanation: The Hopping and Placing reflex is absent in a decorticate animal as it is integrated in the cerebral cortex. Rest of the reflexes are integrated below the cortex.

questions.question: Destruction of the anterior cerebellum in a decerebrate animal leads to

options.C: Increased rigidity via alpha motor neuron

questions.explanation: Destruction of the anterior cerebellum in a decerebrate animal leads to an increased rigidity via alpha motor neuron. If the anterior lobe of the cerebellum is removed in a decerebrate animal, extensor muscle hyperactivity is exaggerated (decerebellate rigidity). This cut eliminates cortical inhibition of the cerebellar fastigial nucleus and secondarily increases excitation to vestibular nuclei. Subsequent dorsal root section does not reverse the rigidity, hence proving that the rigidity is due to activation of motor neurons independent of the gamma loop.

questions.question: Upper Motor Neurons (UMN) include
questions.explanation: Upper motor neurons typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons. The corticospinal tract contains a population of large myelinated fibers with a mean diameter of 16 micrometers. These fibers originate from giant pyramidal cells, called Betz cells, that are found only in the primary motor cortex.

questions.question: A 30-year-old man meets with an accident and develops spinal cord transection. Which of the following features will be seen as a result of pyramidal tract injury below the level of motor decussation?
questions.explanation: Cutting the pyramidal tract below the decussation (UMN lesion) causes an abnormal plantar extensor reflex (positive Babinski sign). It initially causes muscles to become weak and flaccid, but eventually leads to spasticity, hypertonia (increased resistance to passive movement), and hyperactive stretch reflexes.

questions.question: A 36-year-old male patient presented to the ER following a road traffic accident. Which of the following features would not be present if there is a corticospinal tract involvement?
questions.explanation: Cog-wheel rigidity is not seen if there is a corticospinal tract involvement. Cogwheel rigidity is seen in extrapyramidal tract involvement when there is a tremor superimposed on hypertonia (e.g., Parkinsonism). In an upper motor neuron lesion, there is damage to the corticospinal or corticobulbar fibers. If the corticospinal fibers are damaged, it leads to diminished or loss of superficial reflexes, shows an extensor plantar response (Babinski's sign) with loss of fine skilled movement and spasticity.

questions.question: While exercising, a 42-year-old woman developed a sudden onset of tingling in her right leg and an inability to control movement in that limb. A neurologic exam showed a hyperactive knee jerk reflex and a positive Babinski sign. Which of the following is not true regarding her condition?

options.A: Reflexes can be modified by impulses from various parts of the CNS
options.B: Reflexes may involve simultaneous contraction of some muscles and relaxation of others. Reflexes are chronically suppressed after spinal cord transection.
options.C: Reflexes often occur without conscious perception
options.D: The effects of spinal cord transection on reflexes are immediate and permanent

questions.explanation: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of spinal cord transection, which is characterized by an exaggeration of reflexes and not suppression. Upper motor neurons typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons. Damage to these neurons, as in transection of the spinal cord, initially causes muscles to become weak and flaccid but eventually leads to spasticity, hypertonia (increased resistance to passive movement), hyperactive reflexes, and abnormal plantar extensor reflex (positive Babinski sign).

questions.question: Skilled voluntary movement is initiated by
questions.explanation: Commands for voluntary movements originate in cortical association areas. The corticospinal and corticobulbar system (originating in the motor cortex located in the precentral gyrus) is the primary pathway for the initiation of skilled voluntary movement. The movements are planned in the cortex as well as in the basal ganglia and the lateral portions of the cerebellar hemispheres. The basal ganglia and cerebellum funnel information to the premotor and motor cortex by way of the thalamus. Motor commands from the motor cortex are relayed in large part via the corticospinal tracts to the spinal cord. Movement sets up alterations in sensory input from the special senses and from muscles, tendons, joints, and the skin. This feedback information, which adjusts and smooths movement, is relayed directly to the motor cortex and to the spinocerebellum. Control of voluntary movement: Idea - Plan - Cortical association areas - Basal ganglia; Execute - Premotor and motor cortex; Movement - Lateral cerebellum - Intermediate cerebellum

questions.question: In the homunculus, which of the following has maximum representation?
questions.explanation: In a homunculus, the more the representation of an area, the more precise the movements are. The relative sizes of the cortical receiving areas of the sensory homunculus are proportionate to the use of the part. The sizes of these areas are directly proportional to the number of specialized sensory receptors in each respective peripheral area of the body. Some body parts are represented by large areas in the somatic cortex - the lips the greatest of all, followed by the face and thumb, whereas the trunk and lower part of the body are represented by relatively small areas. questions.explanation: As seen from the figure given below, the thumb has the maximum representation. questions.question: While doing a neurosurgical procedure, the paracentral lobules of both hemispheres were damaged. It will lead to which of the following?
questions.explanation: Hip, Knee, Ankle, Toes, Trunk, and appendage motor homunculus; Elbow, Wrist, Hand, Thumb; Neck, Eyelid, and eyeball, Face, Lips, Jaw, Tongue, Swallowing, and articulation. Damage to both paracentral lobules will cause paraplegia. The paracentral lobule is the medial continuation of the precentral and postcentral gyri. It controls motor and sensory innervations of the contralateral lower extremity. It is also responsible for the control of defecation and urination.

questions.question: Setting posture before planned movement is associated with
questions.explanation: The premotor cortex may be concerned with setting posture at the start of a planned movement and getting the individual prepared to move. It is most involved in control of proximal limb muscles needed to orient the body for movement. It is located anterior to the precentral gyrus, on the lateral and medial cortical surface; it also contains a somatotopic map almost identical to the topographic organization in primary motor cortex with the mouth and face areas located most laterally. As one moves upward, the hand, arm, trunk, and leg areas are encountered. This region receives input from sensory regions of the parietal cortex and projects to primary motor cortex (M1), the spinal cord, and the brainstem reticular formation. A special class of neurons called mirror neurons becomes active when a person performs a specific motor task or when he or she observes the same task performed by others. These neurons transform sensory representations of acts that are heard or seen into motor representations of these acts.

questions.question: A quadriplegic man with a high cervical lesion develops sudden onset of flushing, sweating, pounding headache, and hypertension. He has a distended bladder due to a blocked urinary catheter. On immediate drainage of the urinary bladder and repositioning him from supine to reclining, his symptoms resolve. Which of the following is false regarding the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: SBP may rise over 200 mm Hg
options.B: Major portion of the body's skeletal muscle go into extensor spasm
options.C: Large areas of the body break out into profuse sweating

questions.explanation: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of spinal mass reflex, which is seen in patients with a high spinal lesion. A major portion of the body's skeletal muscles goes into strong flexor spasm, and not extensor spasm, in a spinal mass reflex. Mass Reflex: In a spinal animal or human being, sometimes the spinal cord suddenly becomes excessively active, causing massive discharge in large portions of the cord. The usual stimulus that causes this excess activity is a strong pain stimulus to the skin or excessive filling of a viscus, such as over-distention of the bladder or the gut. The mass reflex involves large portions or even all of the cord. The effects are as follows: a major portion of the body's skeletal muscles goes into strong flexor spasms; the colon and bladder are likely to evacuate; the arterial pressure often rises to maximal values, sometimes to a systolic pressure well over 200 mm Hg; and large areas of the body break out into profuse sweating. The mechanism is similar to the mechanism of epileptic seizures, which involve reverberating circuits that occur in the brain instead of in the cord.

questions.question: Detailed Explanations: Each muscle spindle is 3 to 10 millimeters long. It is built around 3 to 12 tiny intrafusal muscle fibers that are attached to the glycocalyx of the surrounding large extrafusal skeletal muscle fibers. Each intrafusal muscle fiber is a tiny skeletal muscle fiber. However, the central region of each of these fibers has few or no actin and myosin filaments. Therefore, this central portion does not contract when the ends do. Instead, it functions as a sensory receptor. The end portions that do contract are excited by small gamma motor nerve fibers. Therefore, it is a gamma motor neuron. Many much smaller gamma motor neurons are located in the spinal cord anterior horns (shown as the yellow efferent fiber). These gamma motor neurons average 5 micrometers in diameter, which go to small, special skeletal muscle fibers called intrafusal fibers or the muscle spindle. These fibers constitute the ends of the muscle spindle, which help control basic muscle tone. Option (b): The alpha motor neurons (shown as the blue efferent fibre) are on an average 14 micrometers in diameter. These fibers branch many times after they enter the muscle and innervate the large skeletal muscle fibers at the motor endplate. Stimulation of a single alpha nerve fiber excites anywhere from three to several hundred skeletal muscle fibers, which are collectively called the motor unit. Option (c): A-beta fibers are fibers for touch and pressure. Option (d): A-delta fibers are fibers for pain and temperature.
